# Interoperating with unmanaged code

> Documentation for Interoperating with unmanaged code.

*Topics available: 47*

- [Blittable and Non-Blittable Types](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/blittable-and-non-blittable-types.md): Learn about blittable and nonblittable types. Blittable data types are commonly represented in managed and unmanaged memory and don't need special handling.
- [Callback Functions](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/callback-functions.md): Read about callback functions, which are code with a managed application that helps an unmanaged DLL function complete a task.
- [Calling a DLL Function](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/calling-a-dll-function.md): Review issues about calling a DLL function that can seem confusing. The function calling process differs depending on if the return type is blittable.
- [COM Interop Sample: COM Client and .NET Server](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/com-interop-sample-com-client-and-net-server.md): Read a code sample that shows the interoperation of a COM client and a .NET server that performs mortgage calculations.
- [COM Interop Sample: .NET Client and COM Server](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/com-interop-sample-net-client-and-com-server.md): Read a code sample that shows how a .NET client accesses a COM server to create a COM coclass instance and call class members to perform mortgage calculations.
- [Compiling an Interop Project](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/compiling-an-interop-project.md): Review how to compile a COM interop project, which are compiled like managed projects if they reference one or more assemblies containing imported COM types.
- [How to: Configure .NET Framework-Based COM Components for Registration-Free Activation](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/configure-net-framework-based-com-components-for-reg.md): Configure .NET-based COM components for registration-free activation. The setup requires a Win32-style application manifest and a .NET component manifest.
- [Consuming Unmanaged DLL Functions](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/consuming-unmanaged-dll-functions.md): Consume unmanaged DLL functions by using the platform invoke service, which lets managed code call unmanaged functions implemented in DLL libraries.
- [Copying and Pinning](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/copying-and-pinning.md): Review how the interop marshaller can copy or pin data that's being marshalled. Copying data places a copy of data from one memory location into another location.
- [Creating a Class to Hold DLL Functions](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/creating-a-class-to-hold-dll-functions.md): Create a managed class wrapper in .NET to hold DLL functions, which helps to encapsulate platform functionality.
- [Creating Prototypes in Managed Code](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/creating-prototypes-in-managed-code.md): Create prototypes in .NET managed code, so you can access unmanaged functions and use attribute fields that annotate method definition in managed code.
- [Default Marshalling Behavior](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/default-marshalling-behavior.md): Learn default marshalling behavior in .NET. Review memory management with interop marshalling, and see default marshalling for classes, delegates, and value types.
- [Default Marshalling for Arrays](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/default-marshalling-for-arrays.md): Understand default marshalling for arrays. Review managed arrays, unmanaged arrays, passing array parameters to .NET code, and passing arrays to COM.
- [Default Marshalling for Objects](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/default-marshalling-for-objects.md): Understand default marshalling for objects. Review marshalling options. Marshal objects to interfaces or variants, variants to objects, and ByRef variants.
- [Default Marshalling for Strings](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/default-marshalling-for-strings.md): Review the default marshalling behavior for strings in interfaces, platform invoke, structures, & fixed-length string buffers in .NET.
- [Deploying an Interop Application](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/deploying-an-interop-application.md): Deploy an interop application, which usually has a .NET client assembly, interop assemblies of distinct COM type libraries, and registered COM components.
- [Exposing COM Components to the .NET Framework](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/exposing-com-components.md): Know the process of exposing COM components to .NET. COM components are valuable in managed code as middle-tier business applications or isolated functionality.
- [Exposing .NET components to COM](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/exposing-dotnet-components-to-com.md): Expose .NET components to COM. Qualify .NET types for interoperation. Apply interop attributes. Package an assembly for COM. Consume a managed type from COM.
- [How to: Add References to Type Libraries](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/how-to-add-references-to-type-libraries.md): Understand how to add references to type libraries in Visual Studio or for command-line compilation.
- [How to: Create COM Wrappers](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/how-to-create-com-wrappers.md): Create Component Object Model (COM) wrappers using Visual Studio or .NET tools (Tlbimp.exe and Regasm.exe). Both methods generate two types of COM wrappers.
- [How to: Create Wrappers Manually](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/how-to-create-wrappers-manually.md): Create wrappers of COM types manually. Use an existing IDL file or type library, or create managed declarations and export the assembly to a type library.
- [How to: Generate Interop Assemblies from Type Libraries](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/how-to-generate-interop-assemblies-from-type-libraries.md): Generate interop assemblies from type libraries. Use Type Library Importer (Tlbimp.exe) to convert coclasses and interfaces from a COM type library to metadata.
- [How to: Generate Primary Interop Assemblies Using Tlbimp.exe](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/how-to-generate-primary-interop-assemblies-using-tlbimp-exe.md): Learn how to generate primary interop assemblies using the Type Library Importer (Tlbimp.exe) that's provided by the Windows SDK.
- [How to: Implement Callback Functions](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/how-to-implement-callback-functions.md): See how to implement callback functions. In this example, a managed application, using platform invoke, prints the handle value for each window on a computer.
- [How to: Map HRESULTs and Exceptions](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/how-to-map-hresults-and-exceptions.md): Review how to map HRESULT values returned from COM methods to exceptions thrown by .NET methods. The runtime handles the transition between COM and .NET.
- [How to: Migrate Managed-Code DCOM to WCF](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/how-to-migrate-managed-code-dcom-to-wcf.md): Migrate Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM) managed code calls between servers and clients to Windows Communication Foundation (WCF).
- [How to: Reference .NET Types from COM](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/how-to-reference-net-types-from-com.md): Reference .NET types from COM. VB clients can view a .NET object in the object browser, but C++ clients must reference a TLB file with the \#import directive.
- [How to: Register Primary Interop Assemblies](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/how-to-register-primary-interop-assemblies.md): Register primary interop assemblies using the Assembly Registration Tool (Regasm.exe), and read about other issues related to interop assemblies.
- [Identifying Functions in DLLs](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/identifying-functions-in-dlls.md): Identify functions in DLLs. A DLL function's identity consists of a function name or ordinal, and the DLL file name in which the implementation can be found.
- [Importing a Type Library as an Assembly](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/importing-a-type-library-as-an-assembly.md): Import a type library, which contains COM type definitions, as an assembly. Learn ways to create metadata from a type library, resulting in an interop assembly.
- [Interoperating with unmanaged code](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/index.md): Review interoperation with unmanaged code. The CLR conceals from clients and servers how the object models of .NET components and unmanaged code differ.
- [Interop Marshaling](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/interop-marshalling.md): Get started with interop marshalling, which governs how data is passed in method arguments and return values between managed and unmanaged memory during calls.
- [Marshalling a Delegate as a Callback Method](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/marshalling-a-delegate-as-a-callback-method.md): Learn to marshal a delegate as a callback method. See an example of how to pass delegates to an unmanaged function that's expecting function pointers.
- [Marshalling Classes, Structures, and Unions](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/marshalling-classes-structures-and-unions.md): Review how to marshal classes, structures, and unions. View samples of marshalling classes, structures with nested structures, arrays of structures, and unions.
- [Marshalling Data with COM Interop](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/marshalling-data-with-com-interop.md): See articles covering the marshalling of data with COM interop. The Tlbimp.exe and Tlbexp.exe tools convert between a COM type library and an interop assembly.
- [Marshalling Data with Platform Invoke](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/marshalling-data-with-platform-invoke.md): Marshal data with platform invoke in .NET. See a list of data types used in Windows APIs and C-style functions, and find their .NET managed type equivalents.
- [Marshalling Different Types of Arrays](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/marshalling-different-types-of-arrays.md): Marshal different array types, like integers by value or reference, 2-dimensional integers by value, strings by value, and structures with integers or strings.
- [Marshalling Strings](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/marshalling-strings.md): Review how to marshal strings. See options for marshalling strings by value or reference, as a result, in a structure or class by value or reference, and more.
- [MsgBox Sample](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/msgbox-sample.md): See a sample of passing string types by values as In parameters using MsgBox. It shows when to use the EntryPoint, CharSet, and ExactSpelling fields in .NET.
- [Packaging a .NET Framework Assembly for COM](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/packaging-an-assembly-for-com.md): Package a .NET assembly for COM. Gather the list of types that COM applications can consume, versioning and deployment instructions, and the type library.
- [Passing Structures](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/passing-structures.md): Understand how to pass structures and classes to unmanaged functions. Learn about the StructLayoutAttribute attribute, which you use to define formatted types.
- [Platform Invoke Examples](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/platform-invoke-examples.md): See a platform invoke example that demonstrates how to define and call the MessageBox function in User32.dll.
- [Registering Assemblies with COM](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/registering-assemblies-with-com.md): Register or unregister assemblies with COM using the Assembly Registration Tool (Regasm.exe), which adds information about the class to the system registry.
- [Registration-Free COM Interop](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/registration-free-com-interop.md): Use registration-free COM interop to activate a component without using the Windows registry to store assembly information.
- [Specifying a Character Set](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/specifying-a-character-set.md): Learn how to specify a character set that uses narrow (ANSI) or wide (Unicode) encoding. You can alternatively specify automatic runtime selection.
- [Specifying an Entry Point](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/specifying-an-entry-point.md): Learn to specify an entry point, which identifies a function's location in a DLL. You can rename the function by mapping the entry point to another name.
- [Type equivalence and embedded interop types](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/framework/interop/type-equivalence-and-embedded-interop-types.md): Understand type equivalence between .NET types and members with a managed assembly, and COM types that are embedded into that assembly. For .NET 4 and above.
